title: 109_hr5940
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Comparative Study of Vaccinated and Unvaccinated Populations Act of 2006". The Congress emphasizes the importance of childhood immunizations in promoting overall health outcomes and preventing infectious diseases. The number of immunizations administered has significantly increased in recent years, contributing to the reduction of vaccine-preventable diseases. Childhood immunizations have increased significantly in recent years, but little safety testing has been done for the interaction effects of multiple vaccines. The strategy of early childhood immunization against various diseases has not been fully tested for safety or overall health outcomes. Public confidence in public health management relies on rigorous testing of state-mandated vaccination programs. Vaccination programs are rigorously tested for safety and verified to produce superior health outcomes. There are populations in the United States that do not vaccinate, providing a comparison group for health outcomes. No comparative studies on these outcomes have been conducted, but with concerns rising over childhood neurodevelopmental disorders, such studies are becoming urgent. A study will be conducted on health outcomes in vaccinated and unvaccinated American populations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to compare health outcomes in vaccinated and unvaccinated populations in the United States, specifically looking at the risk of autism. Investigators must be objective and qualified for the study. The study will include populations in the US that have traditionally remained unvaccinated for religious or other reasons, such as the Old Order Amish and members of clinical practices like the Homefirst practice in Chicago. The Secretary will issue a request for proposals to conduct a study on populations in the US who choose alternative medical practices, including anthroposophic lifestyles, within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. If a proposal is disapproved, the Secretary will provide a written explanation of the reasons.
